<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Introductory
Note</font></b></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">This Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30,
2004 (the &#147;Form 10-K&#148;) contains &#147;forward-looking statements,&#148; as defined in Section&nbsp;27A
of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the &#147;Securities Act&#148;), and Section&nbsp;21E
of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;).&#160; Forward-looking statements are statements
other than historical information or statements of current condition and relate
to future events or the future financial performance of the Company.&#160; Some forward-looking statements may be
identified by use of such terms as &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;intends&#148; or &#147;expects.&#148;&#160; Such forward-looking statements involve known
and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause the actual
results, performance or achievements of the Company to be materially different
from any future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by
such forward-looking statements.&#160; Such
risks, uncertainties, and other factors that may cause such a difference
include, without limitation, those noted under &#147;Risks That May Affect Future
Results&#148; beginning on page 21.&#160; The Company undertakes no obligation to
update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new
information, future events or otherwise.</font></i></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h1 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART I</font></b></h1>

<h1 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h1>

<h2 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item
1.&#160; Business</font></b></h2>

<h2 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<h3 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">General Overview</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Todhunter International, Inc. (the &#147;Company&#148;) is a leading producer and
supplier of rum, brandy, wine and spirits to other beverage alcohol
manufacturers; produces, imports and markets premium branded spirits; bottles
beverage alcohol and other beverages on a contract basis and under its own
labels; and produces vinegar and cooking wine.&#160;
The Company operates four production facilities in the United States and
one in St. Croix, United States Virgin Islands, and purchases certain products
for resale.&#160; The Company is a Delaware
corporation organized in 1970 as a successor to a business founded in the Bahamas
in 1964.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Market share and industry data and rankings disclosed in this report
have been obtained from industry and government publications, as indicated; the
Company has not independently verified this information, although management
believes such data and rankings to be reasonably accurate.&#160; All references in this report to &#147;Fiscal
2004,&#148; &#147;Fiscal 2003&#148; and &#147;Fiscal 2002&#148; refer to the Company&#146;s fiscal years
ended September&nbsp;30 of such year.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Dominant
Supplier of Bulk Alcohol Products</font></b></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Management believes that the Company is the largest supplier of bulk
rum in the United States based on reports of U.S. Imports for Consumption
prepared by the Department of Census and that the Company&#146;s market share of
bulk rum products in the United States is approximately 80%.&#160; Management believes that the Company is the
largest supplier of fortified citrus wine in the United States and is not aware
of any other domestic suppliers of fortified citrus wine.&#160; Management is aware of only one other United
States manufacturer of citrus brandy and citrus spirits and believes that the
Company&#146;s market share for these products is approximately 85%.</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Control
By Angostura Limited</font></b></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Angostura Limited (&#147;Angostura&#148;), a Trinidad-based distiller, has
reported that, as of June&nbsp;17, 2004, it beneficially owned 4,294,583 shares,
representing 68%, of the Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock, $.01 par value per
share (the &#147;Common Stock&#148;).&#160; </font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2004
Developments</font></b></p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>During Fiscal 2004, the
Company continued its strategy of growing its premium branded spirits segment
and capitalizing on its position in the flavored rum category by expanding its
sales force and significantly increasing its marketing budget, partly in
response to increased competition from new product entries by the Company&#146;s
major rum spirits competitors, primarily Bacardi, Diageo, Allied Domecq and
Pernod Ricard.&#160; Fiscal 2004 was a
milestone for the Company in that it was the first time that the Company
executed a print media campaign directed towards consumers.&#160; Fiscal 2004 was also the first year that the
Company sponsored a celebrity entertainer, Kenny Chesney, to increase the brand
awareness of Cruzan Rum.&#160; Kenny Chesney
was the Country Music Awards and American Music Awards &#147;Entertainer of the Year&#148;
in 2004 and is the reigning Academy of Country Music top male vocalist of the
year.&#160; The Company signed a sponsorship
contract with Kenny Chesney for an additional three years.&#160; Management believes that the Company&#146;s brand
promotion strategies have been effective in increasing the sales growth of the
Cruzan Rum brand by 24% during Fiscal 2004.</p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In July&nbsp;2004, the Company
completed the partial consolidation of its bottling operations to reduce
overhead.&#160; However, bottling operations
volume has not met even the Company&#146;s reduced expectations for 2004, which has
caused a continuing loss in this segment.&#160;
The Company has been placing a renewed emphasis on the sales effort in
this segment, seeking other contract bottling opportunities.&#160; The Company has explored other alternatives
in its two bottling facilities, including further consolidation, a partial sale
and shedding less profitable product lines.&#160;
In December&nbsp;2004, management decided to discontinue production of
all products in the Lake Alfred bottling plant with the exception of one
profitable production line bottling vinegar, cooking wine and juices.</p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In August&nbsp;and September&nbsp;2004,
the eyes of three major hurricanes struck within approximately thirty miles of
all of the Company&#146;s facilities in Central Florida.&#160; Physical damage to the Company&#146;s facilities
of less than $100,000 occurred as a result of these hurricanes.&#160; However, while difficult to quantify,
disruptions to business caused by these hurricanes, including several days of
plant shut-downs, prolonged loss of power, product shipment interruptions and
increased labor costs, contributed to lost sales in the premium branded spirits
segment, as well as to the additional costs in the bottling and vinegar and
cooking wine segments.</p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In Fiscal 2004 the Company had a
loss before income taxes of $4.6 million compared to income of $2.4 million in
Fiscal 2003.&#160; After income taxes the
Company&#146;s net loss was $0.9 million in Fiscal 2004 compared to net income of
$3.4 million in Fiscal 2003.&#160; This loss
was primarily due to the increased marketing expenditures in our premium
branded spirits segment, continuing losses in the Company&#146;s bottling operations
and, to a lesser extent, the hurricane disruptions the Company experienced in
its fourth quarter.</p>

<p style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; During June&nbsp;2004, the Company
and Angostura completed a transaction whereby Angostura agreed to invest $10
million in the Company in exchange for 714,285 shares of common stock, which
equates to an equity issue price of $14.00 per share.&#160; The transaction was approved by the Board of
Directors after having been determined to be fair to the public stockholders of
the Company by a Special Committee of Independent Directors of the
Company.&#160; In addition, Angostura
reimbursed one-half of the Company&#146;s expenses in connection with this
transaction.&#160; As a result of this
transaction, Angostura&#146;s ownership of the Company&#146;s stock increased from 64% to
68%.&#160; The Subscription Agreement for this
transaction also provided that the Company use its best efforts to complete a
rights offering pursuant to a registration statement to be filed with the
Securities and Exchange</p>

<p align="center" style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1</font></p>

<div style="line-height:10.5pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='1',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Commission.&#160; The rights offering
is intended to allow each stockholder of the Company, other than Angostura and
its affiliates, to purchase such holder&#146;s approximate pro rata amount of the
number of shares of the common stock of the Company that will permit the public
stockholders in the aggregate to maintain the percentage stock ownership the
public stockholders owned prior to the stock purchase by Angostura.&#160; It is expected that the number of shares
available to be sold pursuant to the rights offering will be approximately
408,000 and the per share purchase price of the rights offering will be the
lesser of $14.00 or the closing price on the American Stock Exchange two days
prior to the effective date of the registration statement.&#160; The Company filed a preliminary registration
statement on August&nbsp;30, 2004.&#160; After
filing the registration statement, the Company determined that it would be in
the best interests of the Company and its stockholders to complete the rights
offering after the Company files this Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal
year ended September&nbsp;30, 2004.&#160; The
Company intends to complete the rights offering during the second quarter of
fiscal 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Business
Segments</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company operates primarily in the
beverage alcohol industry in the United States.&#160;
The Company reports its results in four operating segments and has
unallocated corporate overhead:&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:black;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .7in;text-autospace:none;text-indent:-.2in;"><font size="3" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" color="black" style="color:windowtext;font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">Bulk Alcohol Products (rum, citrus
brandy, citrus spirits, cane spirits, fortified citrus wine, purchased
distilled products and byproducts)</font></p>

<p style="color:black;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .7in;text-autospace:none;text-indent:-.2in;"><font size="3" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" color="black" style="color:windowtext;font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">Premium Branded Spirits (primarily
Cruzan Estate Rums and Cruzan Flavored Rums)</font></p>

<p style="color:black;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .7in;text-autospace:none;text-indent:-.2in;"><font size="3" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" color="black" style="color:windowtext;font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">Bottling Operations (contract
bottling services and proprietary and private label products)</font></p>

<p style="color:black;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .7in;text-autospace:none;text-indent:-.2in;"><font size="3" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" color="black" style="color:windowtext;font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">Vinegar and Cooking Wine (bulk
vinegar, bulk cooking wine, vinegar stock and proprietary and private label
case goods)</font></p>

<p style="color:black;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information regarding the net sales,
operating income (loss) and total assets of each of the Company&#146;s business
segments and information regarding geographic areas is set forth in Note 13 to
the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Bulk Alcohol Products.</font></i>&#160; The Company produces and sells rum, citrus
brandy, citrus spirits, cane spirits and fortified citrus wine in the United
States and internationally.&#160; The Company
also purchases distilled products for resale, including grain alcohol, which is
denatured and packaged and sold as industrial alcohol to hospitals,
universities, fragrance producers and other manufacturers.&#160; The Company is the largest supplier of bulk
rum, citrus brandy and fortified citrus wine in the United States.&#160; The Company sells its bulk alcohol products
to over 40 producers of beverage alcohol in the United States and exports bulk
alcohol products to approximately 20&#160;
foreign countries. The Company&#146;s distilling operations produce a
byproduct, which is sold as animal feed.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Citrus brandy and spirits are distilled from
citrus juice byproducts purchased from manufacturers of citrus juice
concentrate. The Company&#146;s citrus brandy is used primarily as an ingredient in
flavored brandies. Citrus spirits are used primarily as a fortifying ingredient
to increase the alcohol content of the Company&#146;s citrus wine and the wine of
other manufacturers. The Company&#146;s citrus wine is fermented from citrus juice
and fortified with citrus spirits to increase its alcohol content to
approximately 20% by volume. Known as fortified citrus wine, this product is
used primarily as an ingredient in cordials, whiskies and other beverage
alcohol. Rum and cane spirits are distilled from sugar cane molasses and are
sold to other bottlers of rum, producers of beverage alcohol, food companies
and flavor manufacturers.&#160; Rum is also
used in the Company&#146;s premium branded spirits and bottling operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Management believes that the Company&#146;s
proximity to raw materials and its use of citrus byproducts in the production
of bulk alcohol provide it with cost advantages over competitors&#146; products.
Because end products are taxed on a blended rate based upon the ingredients
used rather than on the resulting alcohol content of the end product, beverage
alcohol producers can lower excise taxes on their products by substituting
fortified citrus wine for distilled spirits alternatives. This cost savings
arises because fortified citrus wine is currently subject to federal excise
taxes of $1.57 per gallon, whereas distilled spirits are taxed at $13.50 per
proof gallon (one proof gallon is approximately equivalent in alcohol content
to two and one-half gallons of fortified citrus wine). The ability of beverage
alcohol producers to substitute fortified citrus wine for distilled spirits
varies by end product in accordance with government regulations. For example,
fortified citrus wine may contribute up to 49% of the alcohol content of
cordials and liqueurs, and up to approximately 10% of the alcohol content of
Canadian whiskey. In addition, small quantities of fortified citrus wine may be
used in blended whiskey, rum, brandy and other types of beverage alcohol. </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Florida citrus harvest is generally
during the months from November&nbsp;through June.&#160; The majority of the Florida citrus harvest is
processed as fresh fruit juice or juice concentrate.&#160; A byproduct of citrus juice production is
citrus molasses, which the Company uses as a raw material in its distilling
operations to produce citrus brandy and spirits.&#160; Due to the seasonal availability and short &#147;shelf-life&#148;
of the citrus molasses raw material, the Company produces its estimated annual
customer requirements during a seven month period, and therefore carries a
higher than normal level of inventory in relation to sales during this seven
month period.&#160; Generally, the Company&#146;s
inventory levels increase during this seven month period and when the citrus
harvest ends the Company supplies its customers with citrus brandy and spirits
from inventory from July&nbsp;through October.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Premium Branded Spirits.</font></i>&#160; The Company manufactures, imports, exports,
and markets a variety of premium branded spirits.&#160; The Company&#146;s premium branded spirits include
Cruzan Estate Rums, Cruzan Flavored Rums, Hine Cognac, Conch Republic Rum, Ron
Carlos Rum and Antioqueno Aquardiente. The Company&#146;s primary spirits brand is
Cruzan Rum, which is the fourth-largest premium rum brand in the United States
according to statistics published by Impact Databank and Adams Liquor Handbook,
two leading spirits industry publications.&#160;
</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s strategy is to market high
quality products that satisfy the preferences of consumers of legal drinking
age and to support those&#160; products&#160; with international, national, and regional
marketing&#160; programs.&#160; These programs are intended to extend
consumer brand recognition and brand loyalty.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the United States, the Company sells branded
spirits either through wholesale distributors or directly to state governments
in those states that control alcohol sales.&#160;
Typically, the Company does not have contracts with its distributors
although some states have statutes that limit the Company&#146;s ability to
terminate distributor relationships.&#160;
Outside the United States, the Company typically distributes its
products by selecting the best local distributor for its brands in each
specific market. The Company&#146;s principal export markets for Cruzan Rum are
Canada, Central America, the Caribbean, Scandinavia, the Baltic States, Italy,
France, the Philippines, Israel, New Zealand and the Global Duty Free Markets
(40 countries).&#160; The Company has a
distribution agreement with V&amp;S Vin and Sprit AB (&#147;V&amp;S&#148;) that provides
for joint marketing and for the distribution by V&amp;S of Cruzan products in
the international spirits market where the Company has not already established
a distributor relationship.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The principal raw materials used in
manufacturing and packaging Cruzan Rum are cane molasses, glass bottles,
cartons, and oak barrels, which are used for storage and aging. Currently, none
of these raw materials is in short supply, and there are adequate sources from
which they may be obtained.&#160; See
discussion under &#147;Raw Materials&#148; for additional disclosures related to sourcing
cane molasses and glass bottles.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The alcohol industry is highly competitive
and there are many brands sold in the consumer market. Trade information
indicates that the Company is one of the smaller branded spirit suppliers in
the United States in terms of revenues, although Cruzan Rum has been recognized
as one of the fastest growing brands in the United States and Global Duty Free
Markets by Impact Magazine and Adams, two leading industry publications.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
of the United States Treasury Department regulates the wine and spirits
industry with respect to production, blending, bottling, sales, advertising and
transportation of alcohol products.&#160;
Also, each state regulates advertising, promotion, transportation, sale,
and distribution of such products.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There are no federal regulations that require
minimum aging to be designated rum. However, due to the Company&#146;s high quality
standards, the Company ages its Cruzan Estate Rums for two to five years and
certain of the Company&#146;s super premium rums are aged up to twelve years. Due to
the Company&#146;s own aging requirements, production of Cruzan Estate Rums is
scheduled to meet demand two to three years in the future.&#160; Accordingly,&#160;
inventories&#160; are&#160; larger&#160;
in relation&#160; to sales&#160; and&#160;
total&#160; assets&#160; than&#160;
would&#160; be&#160; normal&#160;
for most&#160; other businesses.
Management expects to continue to increase the Company&#146;s inventory of barrel
aged rums to meet increased sales in the future.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Bottling Operations.</font></i>&#160; The Company&#146;s bottling operations include
contract bottling services and the production, bottling and marketing of
distilled spirits under its own proprietary labels and under the private labels
of retailers.&#160; The Company&#146;s primary
bottling operations are located in Florida and primarily serve customers in the
Southeastern United States.&#160; The Company
also produces and sells proprietary label products in the United States Virgin
Islands. </p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Contract bottling products include distilled
spirits, coolers, prepared cocktails and fruit juices.&#160; The Company has two large contract bottling
customers which accounted for 83% of the bottling operations case volume and
49% of bottling operations net sales for the year ended September&nbsp;30,
2004.&#160; One of these contracts is for
three years, expiring December&nbsp;2006, and the other contract is on a
year-to-year basis.&#160; Each contract
provides for advance notification of annual production requirements, although
there are no minimum volume requirements.&#160;
</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s proprietary and private label
products include rum, gin, vodka, tequila, cordials and various whiskies.&#160; The Company&#146;s proprietary label products are
marketed in the popular-price category of the distilled spirits market.&#160; The Company has one large private label
customer which accounted for approximately 4% of bottling operations case
volume and 11% of bottling operations net sales for the year ended September&nbsp;30,
2004.&#160; Net sales from this customer are
based on short-term arrangements that may terminate at any time. Although the
Company does not have long-term contracts with its private label customers,
management believes that its relations with its customers are good.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company sells its proprietary and private
label spirits to distributors located primarily in the Southeastern United
States.&#160; The Company does not have
contracts with distributors for its proprietary products.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Vinegar and Cooking Wine.</font></i>&#160; To complement its distilling, winery and
bottling operations, the Company produces vinegar, vinegar stock, and cooking
wine.&#160; The Company sells vinegar and
cooking wine to over 700 condiment manufacturers, food service distributors and
major retailers in the United States and Canada. The Company&#146;s sales to
retailers are made under the Company&#146;s proprietary labels and retailers&#146;
private labels.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has three large vinegar and
cooking wine customers which accounted for 32% of the net sales of vinegar and
cooking wine for the year ended September&nbsp;30, 2004.&#160;&#160; Although the Company does not have long-term
supply contracts with its vinegar and cooking wine customers, management
believes that its relations with its customers are good and that the Company&#146;s
products are competitively priced.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Corporate Operations.</font></i>&#160; The Company&#146;s executive offices are located
in West Palm Beach, Florida and certain of the expenses of the Company&#146;s
executive offices are not allocated to the operating segments described
above.&#160; These expenses include salaries
and related expenses, legal and professional fees, rent for office space,
utilities and insurance.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Dependence
on Major Customers</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No single customer was responsible for more
than 10% of the Company&#146;s consolidated net sales during fiscal 2004.&#160; The Company has five major customers in its
bulk alcohol products segment, three major customers in its bottling operations
segment, and three major customers in its vinegar and cooking wine segment, the
loss of one or more of these major customers in any of these segments could
have a material adverse effect on that segment. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Production</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s principal domestic production
facilities are located in Lake Alfred and Auburndale, Florida, both near
Orlando and central to Florida&#146;s citrus growing region. The two plants have
similar distilling, bottling and winery operations, allowing the Company to
shift production from one plant to the other. The Lake Alfred plant also has a
vinegar production facility. Both plants are near major highways and are
serviced by a railroad, providing good transportation access. The Company has a
cold storage, warehousing and plastic bottle manufacturing facility in Winter
Haven, Florida. The Company also operates a winery and vinegar production
facility in Louisville, Kentucky. The Company&#146;s rum production facilities are
located in St.&nbsp;Croix, United States Virgin Islands. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Distilling.</font></i>&#160; The Company begins its distilling process
with citrus or cane molasses, which is fermented for approximately two to four
days. Once fermented, the product has an average alcohol content of 9% by
volume, which is increased to approximately 95% through distillation. The
alcohol is further purified through rectifying columns which remove impurities.
The finished product is stored in stainless steel tanks, except for rum, which
is</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">generally stored in wooden barrels for aging purposes. The Lake Alfred,
Auburndale and Virgin Islands facilities can produce, on a combined basis, up
to 23 million gallons of distilled products per year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Winery.</font></i>&#160; Wine is produced by the fermentation of
citrus or grape juice. After fermentation, the wine is fortified by the
addition of distilled citrus spirits to raise its alcohol content to
approximately 20% by volume. Fortified citrus wine is sold to producers of
beverage alcohol. The wineries are physically segregated from the distilling
operations and have their own sets of fermenting and storage tanks. The Lake
Alfred, Auburndale and Louisville facilities can produce, on a combined basis,
up to 30&nbsp;million gallons of wine per year. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Bottling.</font></i>&#160; The Lake Alfred and Auburndale plants both
have automated, high-speed bottling lines capable of filling up to 600 12-ounce
containers per minute. The Lake Alfred plant has two lines that are used
primarily to bottle vinegar, cooking wine and juices, two lines that are used
to bottle proprietary and private label products and one line to bottle premium
branded spirits. In December&nbsp;2004, management decided to discontinue
production of all products in the Lake Alfred bottling plant with the exception
of one profitable production line bottling vinegar, cooking wine and
juices.&#160; The Auburndale plant has two
lines that are dedicated to bottling coolers and prepared cocktails and three
lines that bottle proprietary and private label products and premium branded
spirits. The Company&#146;s warehouse storage areas can accommodate up to 1,000,000
cases. The Company&#146;s plant in the Virgin Islands has one line capable of
bottling up to 250,000 cases per year.&#160;
The Company distills and ages its own rum, but generally produces its
other proprietary and private label products from alcohol purchased from third
parties. Depending on the particular formula for a product, the Company adds
flavoring and/or sugar, reduces the product&#146;s proof and then filters and
bottles the finished product.&#160; The
Company&#146;s bottling capacity is approximately 10 million cases per year. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Vinegar and Cooking Wine.</font></i>&#160; Vinegar is produced by converting alcohol
into acetic acid. Several varieties of vinegar, including white distilled, red
wine, white wine, corn, rice wine, malt, balsamic and apple cider, are produced
at the Lake Alfred and Louisville facilities, which have a combined capacity of
10&nbsp;million grain gallons per year. Cooking wine is produced by the
controlled fermentation of red or white grape juice into wine and is then
denatured with salt or other ingredients.&#160;
Because of this denaturing process, these products are not subject to
federal excise taxes.&#160; Several varieties
of&#160; cooking wine, including red, white,
sherry, golden, marsala and chablis, are produced at the Lake Alfred,
Auburndale and Louisville facilities. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Quality Control.</font></i>&#160; Each of the Company&#146;s facilities is equipped
with a quality control laboratory. The Company employs several chemists who
continually test to ensure the quality of raw materials and end products. </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Raw Materials.</font></i>&#160; The cost of raw materials fluctuates
depending upon a number of factors, including crop conditions, weather,
governmental programs and purchases by foreign governments.&#160; </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The principal raw materials used in the
Company&#146;s distilling operations are citrus molasses, a byproduct of citrus
juice production, and cane molasses, a byproduct of sugar production. Citrus
molasses, which is used in the production of citrus brandy and citrus spirits,
accounted for approximately 65% of the raw materials used in the Company&#146;s
distilling operations in Fiscal 2004. Cane molasses, which is used in the
production of rum and cane spirits, accounted for the remaining 35%. Citrus
juice concentrate is the primary raw material used in the Company&#146;s winery
operations. The Company purchases such raw materials from a variety of
suppliers. The Company purchases distilled products, used in its bulk alcohol
products and bottling operations businesses, from several suppliers. Glass
bottles and other materials, such as caps, labels and cardboard cartons, are
used in bottling and packaging and, with the exception of glass bottles, are
available from numerous suppliers.&#160; Alcohol
and grape juice concentrate are the primary raw materials used in the Company&#146;s
vinegar and cooking wine operations.&#160; As
more fully described below, during Fiscal 2004, two suppliers each accounted
for more than 10% of all of the Company&#146;s raw material purchases. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company purchases the majority of its
glass bottle requirements from one supplier. Glass bottle costs are one of the
largest components of the Company&#146;s cost of goods sold.&#160; The glass bottle industry is highly
concentrated with only a small number of producers.&#160; The inability of the Company&#146;s glass bottle
supplier to satisfy the Company&#146;s requirements could adversely affect the
Company&#146;s operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company uses cane molasses as a raw
material for the production of rum at its facilities in St. Croix, United
States Virgin Islands.&#160; The Company
purchases its cane molasses raw material requirements through a single broker
that specializes in the South American and Caribbean molasses markets.&#160; This arrangement is beneficial to the Company
in securing a higher quality molasses at lower prices than the Company could
obtain by going directly to the individual molasses suppliers.&#160; Based on an analysis of the world-wide cane
molasses market provided to the</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Company by the Company&#146;s molasses broker, management believes that
there are adequate supplies of cane molasses available to meet the Company&#146;s
cane molasses raw material requirements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Fluctuations
In Operating Results; Seasonality</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The size and timing of purchase orders and
product shipments can cause operating results to fluctuate significantly from
quarter to quarter, particularly since some customers purchase bulk alcohol
products in significant quantities or place significant orders for contract
bottling services, distilled spirits, vinegar and cooking wine.&#160; Additionally, some Company products generate
higher profit margins than others, and changes in the Company&#146;s product mix
will therefore cause gross margins to fluctuate.&#160; Certain aspects of the Company&#146;s business are
also seasonal, with increased demand for the Company&#146;s contract bottling
services from April&nbsp;to October&nbsp;and increased production of the
Company&#146;s bulk alcohol products from November&nbsp;to June, corresponding to
the Florida citrus harvest.&#160; As a result
of these factors, the Company&#146;s operating results may vary significantly from
quarter to quarter.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Marketing
and Distribution</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Bulk alcohol products are sold primarily in
large quantities through Company-employed salespeople. The Company&#146;s marketing
strategy emphasizes the cost advantages of these products over other
ingredients available to end producers. Bulk alcohol products are sold
primarily to other bottlers, distillers and end producers located in the United
States and exports bulk alcohol products to approximately 20 foreign countries.
</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company manufactures, imports, exports
and markets a variety of premium branded spirits to wholesalers in the United
States and internationally.&#160; The Company&#146;s
marketing and promotional programs for its premium brands are directed at
consumers, retailers and wholesalers and include consumer and trade print
advertising, event sponsorship, product sampling, in-store displays, price
promotions, point-of-sale materials and public relations. &#160;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company sells proprietary and private
label spirits to wholesalers for distribution primarily in the Southeastern
United States. The Company&#146;s marketing strategy for these products places
primary emphasis upon the Company&#146;s cost advantages, directed at wholesalers
and retailers, rather than consumers. Wholesalers market these products to
retailers who then market them directly to consumers.&#160; Although competition for retail shelf space
in the beverage alcohol industry is significant, wholesalers of such products,
and not the Company, generally must address such competition.&#160; Sales of the Company&#146;s premium branded
spirits and proprietary and private label products are generally made FOB (free
on board) at the Company&#146;s facilities and, accordingly, the purchasers of such
products are responsible for the risk of loss and transportation costs. In
addition to its own sales force, the Company works through various brokers to
develop and service its sales to wholesalers and retailers. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s marketing strategy with respect
to its contract bottling services emphasizes the cost advantages and quality of
the Company&#146;s services. Arrangements with bottling customers are typically
negotiated by the Company&#146;s executive officers. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Vinegar and cooking wine are sold primarily
in large quantities to manufacturers, distributors and retailers through the
Company&#146;s own sales force. These products are also sold through wholesalers and
directly to retailers under the Company&#146;s proprietary labels and the private
labels of retailers. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Trademarks and Distribution Agreements</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Trademarks are an important aspect of the
Company&#146;s business.&#160; The Company sells
its products under a number of trademarks, which the Company owns or uses under
license.&#160; The Company&#146;s important trademarks
include Cruzan Rum, Cruzan Estate Rum, Cruzan Flavored Rum, Ron Carlos Rum,
Conch Republic Rum and Edmundo Cooking Wine.&#160;
Throughout its segments, the Company also has various licenses and
distribution&#160; agreements for the sale, or
the production and sale, of its products and products of third parties.&#160; These licenses and distribution agreements
have varying terms and durations.&#160;
Agreements include, among others, import, marketing and distribution
agreements (&#147;Imported Spirits Distribution Agreements&#148;) with Antioqueno
Aguardiente, expiring in May 2006, and Hine Cognac, which is a year to year
renewable arrangement for services to be performed by the Company.&#160; The Company also has distribution agreements
with several third parties to distribute Cruzan Rum in foreign countries,
including V&amp;S Vin and Sprit AB (&#147;V&amp;S&#148;) for V&amp;S to distribute Cruzan
products in the international spirits market.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All of the Company&#146;s Imported Spirits
Distribution Agreements may be terminated if the Company fails to meet certain
performance criteria.&#160; The Company
believes it is currently in compliance with all material terms of its Imported
Spirits Distribution Agreements.&#160;
Although there can be no assurance that the&#160; Company&#146;s material Imported Spirits
Distribution Agreements will be renewed, given the Company&#146;s long-term
relationships with its suppliers, the Company expects that such agreements will
be renewed prior to their expiration and does not believe that these agreements
will be terminated.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competition</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The areas of the beverage alcohol industry in
which the Company does business are highly competitive with respect to price,
service and product quality, and there are several companies with substantially
greater financial and other resources than the Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s citrus-based bulk alcohol
products compete primarily with producers of grape-based products. While the
Company is aware of only one other domestic producer of citrus brandy and
spirits, there are several producers of grape-based distilled products. The
Company&#146;s fortified wine business is subject to price competition from various
producers in North America.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s premium branded spirits and
proprietary and private label products compete on a regional and national basis
against other distilled spirits products, including premium labels, mid-price
and popular-price products. The premium branded spirits and proprietary label
products produced by the Company compete with those of companies for whom the
Company performs contract bottling services and to whom the Company sells its
bulk alcohol products. The Company believes that its relationships with its
customers are good, and it has not experienced any adverse effects, such as
termination or non-renewal of ongoing contracts, as a result of competition. In
addition, the Company does not expect to experience any material adverse
effects from such competition in the foreseeable future.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Contract bottling operations compete against
other bottlers located throughout the Southeastern United States.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the United States, the vinegar industry is
dominated by two large manufacturers with approximately 20 vinegar plants and
there are about a dozen smaller manufacturers with an aggregate of
approximately 24 vinegar plants.&#160; Since
vinegar is a low margin commodity, the sale of vinegar is limited to within a
small radius of a particular manufacturing plant due to the cost of shipping to
the customer.&#160; Therefore, with the
exception of certain higher margin specialty vinegars which are sold throughout
the United States, the majority of the Company&#146;s vinegar products are only
competitive within a limited radius of the Company&#146;s manufacturing facility,
generally 200 to 500 miles.&#160; The Company&#146;s
higher margin cooking wine products are sold throughout the United States and
Canada.&#160; Although published data is not
available, management is not aware of any competitors of the Company&#146;s size and
believes that the Company is the largest supplier of cooking wine in the United
States.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Regulation
and Taxation</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
of the United States Treasury Department regulates the wine and spirits
industry with respect to production, blending, bottling, sales, advertising and
transportation of alcohol products.&#160;
Also, each state regulates advertising, promotion, transportation, sale
and distribution of alcohol products. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to federal and state environmental
requirements, the Company is required to obtain permits and licenses to operate
certain facilities, and to treat and remove effluents discharged from its
distilling, winery and bottling operations. Management believes it is presently
in material compliance with all applicable federal and state regulations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Beverage alcohol produced and bottled by the
Company is subject to federal excise taxes. As of September&nbsp;30, 2004,
excise taxes were being imposed at flat rates of $13.50 per proof gallon for
distilled spirits and $1.57 per gallon for fortified wine. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s fortified wine products, as an
ingredient of beverage alcohol, have a cost advantage under the component
method of taxation, which taxes wine at a lower rate than distilled spirits.
Changes in, or the elimination of, the component method of taxation, as it
relates to wine, could have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s results
of operations. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Employees</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of September&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company
had approximately 415 full-time employees. Additional workers are generally
employed at the Company&#146;s bottling facilities during the summer months, when
the bulk of contract</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">bottling takes place. None of the Company&#146;s employees is a member of
any labor union, nor are there any collective bargaining agreements between the
Company and its employees, with the exception of 35 of the Company&#146;s 55 United
States Virgin Islands employees.&#160;
Management believes that its relations with its employees are good. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information
about Foreign and Domestic Operations and Export Sales</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has facilities in Florida and
Kentucky for the production of bulk alcohol products, premium branded spirits,
contract bottling services, vinegar and cooking wine.&#160; The Company sells its products and services
primarily to customers in the United States but also exports certain products
to foreign countries, primarily in Europe, Canada, Central America and the
Caribbean.&#160; The Company&#146;s rum production
facilities are located in St. Croix, United States Virgin Islands.&#160; Bulk rum produced in the Virgin Islands is
sold primarily to other bottlers of rum, producers of beverage alcohol, food
companies and flavor manufacturers located in the United States, but is also
sold to foreign countries in the Caribbean, South America and Europe.&#160; See Note 13 to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial
statements for additional information about the Company&#146;s foreign and domestic
operations and export sales.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 2.&#160;
Properties</font></b></h2>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company owns all of its principal
production facilities, including all related land, buildings, and equipment. The
Lake Alfred facility consists of four principal buildings with approximately
250,000 total square feet on 32 acres. The Auburndale facility consists of
three principal buildings with approximately 250,000 total square feet on 16
acres. The Louisville facility consists of three principal buildings with
approximately 60,000 total square feet on 27.5 acres. The Winter Haven facility
consists of five principal buildings with approximately 260,000 total square
feet on 30 acres. The Virgin Islands facility consists of 11 principal
buildings with approximately 140,000 total square feet on 33 acres.&#160; The Company leases approximately 10,000
square feet of office space in West Palm Beach, Florida for its executive
offices and 2,600 square feet of office space in Jupiter, Florida for its
marketing operations.&#160; Management
believes that all of its facilities, both owned and leased, are adequate and
suitable for operations in the foreseeable future.&#160; However, management may undertake the
expansion of certain facilities from time to time in the ordinary course of
business.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 3.&#160; Legal
Proceedings</font></b></h2>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company and its subsidiaries are subject
to litigation from time to time in the ordinary course of business.&#160; None of these routine legal proceedings are
material.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item </font></b>4.&#160;
Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders</h2>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No matters were submitted to security holders
during the fourth quarter of Fiscal 2004. </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\JMS\jpatrow\04-15066-1\task259499\15066-1-ba-01.htm',USER='jpatrow',CD='Dec 21 12:58 2004' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h1 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART II</font></b></h1>

<h1 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h1>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 5.&#160; Market
for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer
Purchasers of Equity Securities</font></b></h2>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Common Stock trades on the
American Stock Exchange under the symbol &#147;THT.&#148;&#160;
Table 1 below sets forth the high and low closing quotations of the
Company&#146;s Common Stock for each quarter during the past two fiscal years. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The number of stockholders of record as of December&nbsp;3,
2004 was 28.&#160; In addition, based upon a
list of non-objecting beneficial owners, there were at least 475 beneficial
owners as of January&nbsp;2004.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No dividends were paid to stockholders during
Fiscal 2003 and Fiscal 2004. The Company intends to continue to retain earnings
for use in its business and, therefore, does not anticipate declaring or paying
cash dividends in the foreseeable future.&#160;
The payment of cash dividends is also limited by the Company&#146;s credit
agreement. Also, see &#147;Financial Liquidity and Capital Resources,&#148; included in
Item 7.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">9</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<div>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 6.&#160;
Selected Financial Data</font></b></h2>

<h2 style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;punctuation-wrap:simple;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.5in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The selected financial data in Table 2 below
are derived from the Company&#146;s audited consolidated financial statements. These
data are qualified by reference to, and should be read in conjunction with, the
consolidated financial statements and related notes and &#147;Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148;
included elsewhere herein. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>
